LOAN SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
   
The Proposal  A  loan  of  $500,000,000  is  proposed  for  Countercyclical  Support 
(VIE-CS). The VIE-CS is to be provided as a single tranche under the 
Countercyclical Support Facility (CSF) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). 
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Public sector management (economic and public 
affairs management) 
Theme (subtheme): Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic 
stability) 
Location impact: National (high) 
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment 
   
The Program  The global economic downturn, triggered by the collapse of the US 
Rationale  subprime mortgage market, has turned into one of the sharpest global 
economic recessions in modern history. Most developed economies are 
in  deep  recession  in  2009,  and  the  pace  of  economic  growth  in 
developing countries has declined significantly, and has in some cases 
become  negative.  The  latest  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF) 
projections suggest that economic growth in developed countries this 
year will contract by 3.8%. The volume of world trade is expected to fall 
by 12.2% and foreign direct investment (FDI) is estimated to fall by 
about 30% from 2008 levels. Viet Nam has been severely affected by 
the  global  economic  downturn  because  of  the  country’s  increasing 
dependence on FDI inflows and exports to support its high economic 
growth  rate,  since  its  successful  accession  to  the  World  Trade 
Organization (WTO) in January 2007. FDI disbursement declined by 
about 18.4% and exports dropped by 10.2% in the first half of 2009. FDI 
approval fell by 75% during the same period. Remittance inflows and 
tourist arrivals also dropped significantly. The global financial crisis has 
affected the Government’s market access for budget financing. As a 
result, the Government has issued only a limited amount of domestic 
bonds  since  early  2009,  as  bond  yields  in  the  market  remain 
significantly higher than the ceilings set by the Government.  
 
The  Government  is  concerned  about  the  potential  adverse  poverty 
impacts  of  significantly  slower  economic  growth.  Because  of  the 
country’s young demographic profile, about 1.7 million young workers 
enter the country’s labor force annually. During 2006–2007, with annual 
average gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 7.6%, only about 
800,000 jobs were created annually. With growth projected to decline to 
5%  or  less,  unemployment  and  underemployment  could  increase 
significantly. At the same time, the social security system is still in a 
very early stage of its development. The Government’s cash transfer 
program  has  limited  coverage,  and  is  fraught  with  implementation

ii 
 
problems. Therefore, preventing a collapse of economic activities and 
sustaining employment are high priorities. 
 
The Government has announced a significant fiscal stimulus package 
to  counter  the  potential  adverse  impacts  of  the  global  economic 
downturn. The fiscal stimulus package is intended to bolster the primary 
strengths of the economy, maintain GDP growth above 5%, and ensure 
social stability. It broadly consists of four pillars: (i) enhancing state 
investment  funded  from  the  budget  and  additional  bond  issues; 
(ii) exemptions,  reductions,  and  deferments  in  taxes,  intended  to 
support  business  and  bolster  domestic  consumption;  (iii) interest 
subsidies and credit guarantees intended to keep credit flowing; and 
(iv) additional budget expenditure for social welfare. 
 
It is in the context of the second-round effects on the real economy and 
the emerging fiscal constraint that the Government has requested ADB 
to  provide  a  CSF  of  $500 million  to  support  its  public  expenditure 
program  for  2009.  The  request  for  financing  stemmed  from  the 
Government’s  concerns  about  ensuring  predictability  in  its  budget 
financing  since  (i)  market  financing  access  on  reasonable  terms  is 
expected to be limited, and (ii) a larger fiscal stimulus is now needed.  
Objective, Scope,  The  objective  of  the  VIE-CS  loan  is  to  provide  support  for  the 
and Coverage of  Government’s countercyclical spending program for 2009 and therefore 
Loan  ensure predictability in its budget financing given limited market access 
and  the  need  for  a  temporary  fiscal  expansion.  This  will  allow  the 
Government to promote economic recovery, protect its social spending 
and poverty alleviation programs and objectives, and continue with its 
longer term development objectives in 2009.   
Financing Plan  The Government has requested a loan of $500,000,000 under the CSF 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility plus 200 basis points; a 5-year term, including a grace 
period  of  3  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  Loan 
Agreement. 
 
Period and  The period specified for the VIE-CS will be from 1 September 2009 to 
Tranching  31 December 2010, with a single tranche loan of $500 million to be 
disbursed  when  the  Government  has  met  the  conditions  for  loan 
effectiveness. 
   
Counterpart Funds  The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  counterpart  funds 
generated  by  the  loan  proceeds  to  help  maintain  current  social 
expenditure and infrastructure spending. 
   
Executing Agency   State Bank of Viet Nam (SBV)

iii 
Implementation  SBV will be the Executing Agency responsible for overall execution and 
Arrangements  coordination  of  the  Government's  countercyclical  program  and  for 
reporting to ADB.  The Government will establish a committee, chaired 
by MPI, comprising officials from SBV, MOF, and other line ministries. 
The committee will be responsible for monitoring and overseeing the 
implementation  of  the  Government's  countercyclical  programs 
supported under the CSF loan. The committee will meet quarterly to 
report  on  progress  of  implementation  of  the  Government's 
countercyclical programs supported under the loan. The committee will 
also  report  on  overall  progress  of  the  Government's  countercyclical 
public spending program. ADB may be invited to participate in some of 
the meetings as an observer.  At the implementation level, SBV and 
MOF will be responsible for administering the disbursement of loan 
proceeds  from  ADB  and  maintaining  accounts.  MPI  will  select  and 
submit the proposals for activities to be supported under the CSF loan. 
The line ministries will assist SBV in monitoring activities carried out by 
their ministries. 
   
Procurement and  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
Disbursement  costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured 
in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources. The loan proceeds 
will be disbursed to the Borrower in accordance with the provisions of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans. 
   
Benefits and  The VIE-CS will provide significant benefits and have a positive impact 
Beneficiaries  on the economy and poor because of the following:  
 
(i)  Higher infrastructure spending will generate long-term growth, 
stimulate investment, create jobs, and raise incomes. 
(ii)  Improved  social  sector  outcomes  will  result  from  increased 
spending;  better  targeted  social  assistance  programs; 
implementation of the Government’s social welfare efforts, in 
particular  on  61  districts  identified  as  being  the  poorest  in 
Viet Nam  and  assistance  provided  to  affected  eligible 
enterprises to reduce the unemployment impact of the crisis. 
(iii)  The VIE-CS will help close the budget financing gap within a 
medium-term  fiscal  program,  thereby  supporting  economic 
growth and macroeconomic stability. 
   
Risks and  The VIE-CS supplements financing from other ADB programs such as 
Assumptions  the  proposed  second  subprogram  of  the  fifth  Support  for  the 
Implementation of the Poverty Reduction Program (SIPRP V), scheduled 
for consideration by ADB’s Board of Directors in October 2009. The 
SIPRP  supports  the  Government’s  policy  reform  efforts,  which  are 
needed  for  the  successful  implementation  of  its  Five-Year  Socio-
Economic Development Plan (SEDP), 2006–2010, including in the areas 
of  public  financial  management  and  pubic  administration,  tax 
administration  reform,  investment  competitiveness,  natural  resource 
management, and social protection.

iv 
 
 
However, the VIE-CS has risks:  
 
(i)  The  global  financial  crisis  has  adversely  affected  Viet  Nam’s 
economy. A prolonged global recession will reduce economic 
growth further and will feed into higher poverty in 2009 and 
2010. However, these effects on poverty will be partially offset 
through  the  Government’s  large  fiscal  stimulus  to  support 
infrastructure  development  and  other  social  assistance 
programs. 
(ii)  The absorptive capacity of concerned implementing ministries 
and agencies will be stretched and may affect the timeliness and 
effectiveness  of  the  Government’s  countercyclical  spending 
program.  The  Government  has  introduced  several  policy 
measures to expedite disbursements and this will mitigate some 
of these potential constraints. 
(iii)  Program  leakages  and  corruption.  Some  social  assistance 
programs, interest subsidy, and infrastructure are vulnerable to 
leakages,  mis-targeting,  and  corruption.  The  Government  is 
committed to addressing these problems though a number of 
instruments,  including  improved  supervision,  enhanced 
monitoring,  and  continued  reforms  in  public  financial 
management and procurement—supported by the World Bank 
and other development partners.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Countercyclical Support (VIE-CS). The development 
policy  letter  confirming  the  Government’s  countercyclical  program  and  its  medium-term 
development program is in Appendix 1. The status of the Government’s compliance with the 
access criteria is in Appendix 2.1 
 
II.  REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE FROM                                                                
THE COUNTERCYCLICAL SUPPORT FACILITY 
2.  The  proposed  loan  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  (CSF)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) comes at a critical time for Viet Nam. It is designed to maintain the 
momentum of the country’s key development efforts at a challenging time of global financial 
market  failure  and  the  first  global  recession  since  World  War II.  The  global  crisis,  which 
intensified after September 2008, has affected the Viet Nam economy and social sectors in 
several respects: (i) the surge in commodity prices early in 2008 and the subsequent first-round 
effects of the global financial crisis impacted on its domestic financial sector and increased 
downside risks to its external balance in 2008; (ii) the second-round effects of reduced global 
demand have hurt the real economy by stalling its two engines of growth—external trade and 
foreign direct investment (FDI)—with economic growth in 2009 slowing to rates last seen in 
1999; (iii) the impact on fiscal policy has resulted in a decline in tax revenue and a larger 
government budget deficit than initially projected, at a time of limited access to international 
credit markets; and (iv) the economic and fiscal policy impacts threaten to undo recent gains in 
poverty reduction. 
3.  Given the second-round effects on the real economy and the emerging fiscal constraint, 
the Government of Viet Nam asked ADB to provide a countercyclical support loan (VIE-CS) of 
$500 million to support its 2009 and 2010 public expenditure programs. The Government is 
concerned about maintaining economic growth above 5% and protecting jobs and stability. It is 
also concerned about ensuring predictability in its budget financing, given the necessity for 
temporary fiscal stimulus. The Government projects gross financing requirements for 2009 at 
D203.5 trillion, including domestic and external debt that matures in 2009. Therefore, the loan 
will provide additional financing to the Government for the larger fiscal stimulus now needed.  
4.  Adverse effects of the global financial crisis. The economy has been adversely 
impacted by the global economic crisis. This impact is manifested in several ways. Economic 
growth is projected at 3%–5% in 2009, down from an average of 7.6% for the last 4 years. The 
slump in FDI, exports, and remittances are the key factors behind this sharper than expected 
economic slowdown. Viet Nam is also experiencing temporary fiscal constraint because of the 
slowdown. The 2009 budget plan projects government revenue to decline by about 3.0% of 
gross domestic product (GDP) below 2008 levels, primarily because of the slump in resource 
tax revenues. Actual revenue collection in the first half of 2009 was about 5.1% below the target 
specified in the 2009 budget plan. The 2009 overall government budget deficit could rise to 
10.3% of GDP, including the stimulus spending package, up from 4.1% of GDP in 2008, which 
is relatively high by international standards. However, ADB staff estimate that the cyclically 
adjusted (or underlying) budget deficit is about 4.5% of GDP.

5.  Improved macroeconomic management. The Government has made strong efforts to 
maintain macroeconomic management of the increased downside risks to the economy arising 
from (i) its own economic overheating in 2007 and the surge in global commodity prices in early 
2008, and (ii) the global financial crisis that intensified in September 2008. The maintenance of 
macroeconomic stability is reflected in inflation declining from its peak of 28% in August 2008 to 
2.0%  in  August  2009  on  a  year-on-year  basis.  Overall,  the  banking  sector  is  sufficiently 
capitalized. While banks’ nonperforming loans (NPLs)2 have risen slightly, they remained low at 
2.2% for the whole banking system in June 2009. The Government has operated overall budget 
deficits (combined on- and off-budget balances) averaging 4% of GDP in the last 4 years, 
primarily driven by large capital spending accounting for about 30% of on-budget spending. Viet 
Nam remains at low risk of external debt distress despite the recent deterioration in its economic 
conditions and the global downturn, reflecting Viet Nam’s mostly concessional and long-term 
structure of external debt. The outlook for public debt is less favorable. While it has been 
relatively  stable,  at  44.4%  of  GDP,  it  is  moderately  high  for  a  developing  economy  and 
underscores the need for medium-term fiscal consolidation (Appendix 5). However, its external 
position remains vulnerable to modest shocks. Gross international reserves declined from $23.0 
billion at the end of December 2008 to $17.6 billion at the end of June 2009, equivalent to about 
3.7 months  of  import  cover.  Conventionally,  at  least  3.0  months  of  import  coverage  is 
considered a sufficient buffer against modest shocks to the balance of payments. At the same 
time, Viet Nam has a relatively high level of reserves in relation to short term debt. 
 
6.  Large fiscal response. The Government has announced a countercyclical program to 
mitigate  the  potential  severe  impacts  of  the  global  slowdown  on  Viet  Nam.  The  program 
includes both on- and off-budget measures and focuses on increased infrastructure spending, 
temporary tax exemptions, and deferred tax payments intended to support business and bolster 
domestic consumption; interest rate subsidies and credit guarantees intended to keep credit 
flowing; and additional budget expenditure for social welfare. The entire stimulus package is 
estimated to amount to D145.6 trillion. The Government intends to use the loan proceeds from 
the VIE-CS loan to support its countercyclical spending program for 2009 and 2010, and in 
particular  its  longer  term  infrastructure  development  in  irrigation,  transportation,  and  other 
areas.3 
7.  Fiscal space. In the context of its debt burden, the fiscal stimulus package is expected 
not to adversely affect debt sustainability provided that measures undertaken are time bound 
and do not have a permanent impact on deficits. A cross-country comparison drawing on IMF 
publications indicates that the debt stabilizing primary deficit is within manageable bounds in 
Viet Nam.4 Appendix 10 provides details of fiscal stimulus packages in a number of countries. 
 
8.  Donor  coordination.  The  VIE-CS  loan  supplements  ADB  policy  dialogue  with  the 
Government under existing loan programs to Viet Nam and especially under the Support for the 
Implementation of the Poverty Reduction Program (SIPRP) cluster approved by ADB’s Board of 
Directors in December 2008 (Appendix 9). The SIPRP is a series of three annual, single-tranche 
loans  (subprograms)  supporting  the  policy  reform  agenda  of  the  Government  needed  for 
successful  implementation  of  its  medium-term  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan  (SEDP), 
2006–2010. The SIPRP provides parallel financing with the World Bank’s Poverty Reduction

III.  THE GLOBAL CRISIS AND COUNTRY CONTEXT 
A.  The Global Crisis and its Impact on Viet Nam’s Economy 
10.  The global financial turmoil has affected developed and most developing economies, 
including Viet Nam. The impact on developing countries has varied, but generally the crisis 
adversely impacted access to global financial markets; and resulted in a sharp downturn in the 
real  economy  with  ensuing  fiscal  stress,  and  higher  unemployment  and  poverty.  The 
International Monetary Fund projects that the global economy will contract this year by about 
3.8% and only moderately recover next year, as financial market stabilization will take longer 
than previously envisaged. The volume of world trade is expected to fall by 12.2% and FDI is 
estimated to fall by about 30% from 2008 levels. Developing country access to international 
credit will remain curtailed as a consequence. 
 
11.  Four  key  features  of  Viet  Nam’s  recent  economic  developments  are  important  in 
understanding the potential effects of the global economic downturn and the Government’s 
determined  policy  response  to  cope  with  the  impacts.  First,  the  country  is  increasingly 
dependent on FDI inflows and exports to support its high economic growth rate, particularly 
since its successful accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2007. Before 
WTO accession, investment in Viet Nam was dominated by state investment. In 2007, FDI 
disbursement surged by over 90% and continued to expand strongly in 2008 to reach D192.4 
trillion. As a result, the share of FDI in the country’s total investment increased to 31.5% in 2008, 
from 16.2% in 2006. At the same time, Viet Nam traditionally has a very high degree of 
openness to trade, with a trade–GDP ratio of 159% in 2008. Given its high trade intensity, it is 
therefore highly vulnerable to shocks to global demand. Second, Viet Nam entered the global 
economic downturn from a position of domestic economic overheating in late 2007 and early 
2008, necessitating a sharp reorientation in economic policy measures. Third, unlike more 
developed economies in the region, Viet Nam does not have all the same policy levers and 
appropriate institutions to address the series of shocks to the economy effectively, and at times 
had to adopt blunt and unconventional measures such as credit subsidies to mitigate the worst 
effects of the crisis on the macroeconomy and labor market. The Government is well aware of 
the need for more market-based instruments, and is addressing these policy and institutional 
constraints through ongoing reforms including those supported by the SIPRP and the World 
Bank’s PRSC series. Finally, Viet Nam has a young demographic profile, and its social security

system is still in a very early stage of development. Therefore, the global financial crisis has 
major adverse short-term implications for Viet Nam’s labor market and poverty reduction efforts. 
 
12.  The global commodity price surge. Viet Nam has experienced three major shocks to 
its economy in the past 18 months. The first was the surge in global commodity prices that 
spilled over into very high domestic inflation, peaking at 28% in August 2008 on a year-on-year 
basis. This occurred at a time when Viet Nam’s economy exhibited significant signs of economic 
overheating caused by rapid credit and monetary growth, fueled by large inflows of foreign 
investments. Consequently, the domestic financial and asset markets underwent significant 
correction in the first half of 2008. The equity market was impacted, with equity prices collapsing 
by more than two-thirds in 2008. Property prices also fell in the major urban centers. There was 
some capital flight (of which some was disguised through imports of gold) that put pressure on 
the dong exchange rate to depreciate in the first semester of 2008. 
 
13.  First-round effects of the global financial crisis. The global financial crisis intensified 
in September 2008. However, the spillovers from the global financial crisis on the Viet Nam 
domestic  financial  sector—especially  banking—have  been  less  significant  than  in  other 
countries in the region because of limited exposure to troubled US assets, virtually no exposure 
to securitization and off-balance-sheet activities, and of course domestic financial and asset 
markets had already experienced significant correction. The financial health of the domestic 
banking  system  has  improved  in  recent  years.  Overall,  the  banking  system  is  adequately 
capitalized but it remains vulnerable to the economic slowdown, given the rapid credit growth 
seen in the last 2 years. The Government’s international reserves position declined from $23.0 
billion at the end of 2008 to $17.6 billion at the end of June 2009—highlighting continued 
pressure on its external position.  
 
14.  The global credit crunch that emerged in September 2008 hurt Viet Nam as investors 
became risk averse and reduced demand for Viet Nam debt. Yields on the Government’s global 
bond surged significantly, in line with many countries in the region (Figure 1.c). While the yields 
have gradually declined, they remain elevated. As a result, so far this year the Government has 
only issued a small amount of dong-denominated bonds and dollar-denominated bonds in the 
domestic market. The Government has not issued any sovereign bond overseas since 2005. 
 
15.  Second-round effects of the global demand destruction. The second-round effects 
of the global recession on the Viet Nam economy are greater than the impacts of the 1997/1998 
Asian financial crisis. Total exports fell 10.2% in the first semester of 2009. Traditional labor-
intensive sectors experienced larger contractions, with exports of light industrial and handicrafts 
falling by 25%. The tourism sector also suffered significantly, with tourist arrivals falling 20% in 
the first half of 2009. Disbursements of FDI declined by 18.4% in the first semester of 2009. As 
a result, the Viet Nam economy slowed to 3.9% in the first 6 months of 2009 over the same 
period  in  2008,  its  lowest  economic  growth  rate  since  1999,  and  well  below  its  average 
economic growth rate of 7.6% in the last 4 years. Of significant concern for poverty reduction, 
the inflows of remittances have dropped sharply by 26% in the first half of 2009, down to $2.7 
billion from $3.7 billion for the same period in 2008. 
 
16.  With this background, it is expected that economic growth for 2009 will be about 3.0%–
5.0% because of faltering exports, slowing foreign investments, and the drop in remittances. 
These projections translate to lower per capita income growth of 1.5%–3.5% in 2009, thereby 
likely increasing poverty (para. 17).

B.  The Government’s Macroeconomic Management 
19.  Appropriate and responsive policy. The Government’s macroeconomic policy stance 
to the increased downside risks to the economy from the global crisis has been appropriate and

number  of  proactive  measures  aimed  at  increasing  liquidity  in  the  banking  system, 
strengthening the capital base of the banking system, and strengthening SBV’s supervisory

22.  Public finances. With the destruction in global demand since September 2008, and the

However, a large part of the increase in the deficit in the budget plan is due to conservative

an  expected  lower  price  for  fuel  and  its  knock-on  effect  for  crude  oil  royalty  payments. 
Nevertheless, whether the overall deficit reaches 10.3% of GDP will depend on implementation 
and timing of the different fiscal stimulus measures and actual budget revenue outcomes for 
2009. Some of the planned capital spending measures are dependent on financing through 
Government Treasury bonds and thus may be delayed.9 Therefore, the actual stimulus impact 
of the expansion will be less than 3.2% of GDP (netting out projected revenue declines). A 
recent  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  study  suggests  that  the  magnitude  of  the  fiscal 
expansion, discretionary and nondiscretionary components, should depend on the size of the 
output gap.10 Overall, the actual fiscal stimulus in Viet Nam covers the projected negative output 
gap this year (i.e., the gap between potential and actual economic growth), suggesting that the 
size of the fiscal expansion is sufficient (Appendix 3).

24.  Public  debt  sustainability.  Despite  a  significant  increase  in  budget  deficit,  the 
Government’s debt position is projected to be sustainable. The Government’s public debt at the 
end of 2008 was at 44.4% of GDP, 56% of which is external debt. The recent International 
Monetary Fund Article IV Consultation11 concludes that Viet Nam’s debt position is at low risk of 
distress. Most debt is concessional, with a low fixed interest rate and well spread out maturities. 
Under the baseline scenario, the present value of public debt in relation to GDP is projected to 
increase from 37% of GDP in 2008 to 46% in 2013, and decline thereafter to 43% in 2028. 
Stress tests of a one-time 30% depreciation in the dong would increase the present value of 
public debt by 7%, and an increase in debt-creating flows by 10 percentage points of GDP 
would increase the present value of public debt by 8% in 2013. However, these two risks are 
less likely to materialize now. The trade balance position has improved significantly relative to 
last year. Although fiscal stimulus will increase the budget deficit in 2009, a large part of it will be 
financed by government deposits (non-debt creating flows). In addition, the fiscal stimulus 
involves advancing project implementation from 2010, which is expected to reduce the budget 
deficit and debt financing in 2010. Based on IMF projections, Viet Nam requires a primary 
budget deficit of about 3.3% of GDP to stabilize its debt over the medium term. Therefore, Viet 
Nam has sufficient fiscal space as its debt is mostly concessional. 
 
IV.  THE GOVERNMENT’S COUNTERCYCLICAL PROGRAM 
  
25.  The Government announced its countercyclical expenditure program earlier this year 
and the National Assembly endorsed it in June 2009. Like many other developing economies, 
the  national  government  budget  does  not  have  automatic  stabilizers  embedded  on  the 
expenditure side of the budget and its social security system is still in too early a stage of 
development to be an adequate stabilizer (Appendix 10).12 Therefore, it had to announce the 
countercyclical  program,  focusing  on  advancing  infrastructure  projects  already  in  the 
Government’s  investment  pipeline,  tax  cuts  and  deferred  payments  intended  to  support 
business  and  bolster  domestic  consumption,  interest  rate  subsidies  and  credit  guarantees 
intended  to  keep  credit  flowing,  and  additional  budget  expenditure  for  social  welfare.  The 
countercyclical  program  is  designed  to  stimulate  the  economy,  with  particular  focus  on 
protecting employment and social stability. Given that Viet Nam’s social security system is in its 
infancy, the Government feels it needs to use blunt and some unconventional instruments, such 
as credit subsidies, to protect employment and assist the poor and vulnerable groups in the 
community. Much of this additional stimulus is discretionary and temporary in nature, and 
therefore does not undermine the Government’s efforts for medium-term fiscal consolidation. 
Overall, the stimulus package amounts to D145.6 trillion of on- and off-budget programs (Table 
3).

infrastructure program in the 2008 budget and advancing to 2009 priority projects from the 2010 
investment pipeline (Table 3).13 Under current public financial regulations, line agencies are only

27.  Tax measures. Temporary tax exemptions and deferred tax payments for eligible firms 
to the end of 2009 are designed to have had an immediate impact on stimulating household

of the infrastructure spending is only expected to have an impact in the second semester of

tax  relief  measures  apply  to  corporate  income  tax  or  CIT  (for  small  and  medium-sized

and value-added tax (VAT); and amount to D28 trillion. MOF adopted a mix of temporary tax 
exemptions and deferred tax payments to protect its medium-term revenue sustainability efforts 
while providing relief to distressed firms and boosting household income. It projects that these 
measures will cover up to D13 trillion in tax collection in 2009, of which some proportion will be 
deferred payments to the end of 2009 and 2010.  
 
28.  Interest rate subsidies and credit guarantees. The Government introduced a number 
of unconventional measures to provide relief to labor-intensive enterprises, with the objective of 
protecting employment. These included an interest rate subsidy of 4% on short-term working 
capital signed and disbursed from February 2009 to December 2009. The same subsidy is 
applied to medium- and long-term investment loans signed and disbursed from April 2009 to 
December 2011. The interest rate subsidy is designed to partially offset the increase in the cost 
of domestic financing arising from the global financial crisis and SBV’s earlier policy efforts to 
cool the economy. The subsidized loans are extended by the commercial banks and finance 
companies (and reimbursed by SBV) to eligible borrowers on the basis of normal commercial 
principles. A new credit guarantee scheme for SMEs’ capital spending, implemented through 
Vietnam Development Bank (VDB) was also introduced. The guarantee scheme is aimed at 
enterprises with less than 1,000 employees and capital of less than D20 billion. Under the 
scheme, VDB will assess eligible enterprises and issue a guarantee letter for them to borrow 
from commercial banks. SBV has budgeted this subsidy cost at D17 trillion. While interest rate 
subsidies and guarantees could create problems of their own, the Government considers that 
this is one of a few instruments it has available to help keep the flow of credit to enterprises 
under the current situation, and only intends most of it to be a temporary measure. At the same 
time, SBV has upgraded its monitoring and supervision of the credit subsidy scheme. 
 
29.  Social assistance spending. In the absence of national social assistance programs 
that could be quickly scaled up and effectively targeted, the Government announced a package 
of assistance to poor families and community groups vulnerable to falling into poverty as a result 
of the economic slowdown. This underscores the necessity for developing better targeted social 
assistance  programs  over  the  medium  term.  The  package  of  assistance  includes  wage 
subsidies to distressed firms, disaster mitigation programs, and one-off financial assistance and 
housing support to low-income families as a way to mitigate the worst effects of the crisis on the 
most vulnerable in the community. The Government will also extend loans from the National 
Employment Fund to workers laid off for training and self-employment. The Government has 
also focused its social welfare efforts on 61 districts identified as being the poorest in Viet Nam 
with poverty incidence close to 50%, more than 3.5 times of the national average. These

districts span 20 provinces, primarily in the northwest, northeast, north central, and central 
highland regions of the country.  
 
30.  MOF is monitoring implementation and disbursement of key countercyclical spending 
programs. About 80% of unspent infrastructure spending from the 2008 budget was disbursed 
by May 2009. The tax exemptions and deferred payments impacted immediately. As of June 
2009, D370 trillion in credits were disbursed under the subsidy credit scheme, over 90% of 
which was for working capital. The Government recognizes that additional fiscal stimulus could 
also be generated by expediting the disbursement of project loans that have been approved by 
the Government. In this context, the Government has taken steps to simplify and streamline 
regulations governing public investment, and to initiate monthly review meetings to monitor and 
improve official development assistance disbursement. Policy dialogue is also progressing on 
improving public investment between the Government and the Six Banks Group, comprising 
ADB, France Agency for Development (AFD), Japan International Cooperation Agency, Export-
Import Bank of Korea, Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau Entwicklungsbank (KfW), and the World 
Bank.  
 
31.  The effectiveness of the Government’s fiscal stimulus package will depend on better 
budget execution and targeting. The Government’s public financial management (PFM) reforms 
are at an early stage but steady progress is being made in establishing and improving the 
legislative  and  institutional  framework.  The  Law  on  Public  Debt  Management  has  been 
promulgated by the National Assembly and will be effective from January 2010. The new law 
will provide a legal framework for a modern debt management system to monitor public debt, 
analyzing its profile, and resolving and managing related fiscal risks. Implementation of the 2002 
State Budget Law is progressing. At the same time, the Government is working on several items 
of key legislation that will significantly enhance public financial management over the medium 
term. The proposed revision to the Law on State Budget is aimed at (i) introducing a medium-
term expenditure framework and performance-based budgeting; (ii) improving budget execution; 
(iii)  enhancing  budget  supervision,  monitoring,  and  implementation;  and  (iv)  increasing 
decentralization of budget management. A new integrated computerized financial management 
system (TABMIS) has been rolled out since 2008 to strengthen expenditure management and 
control. An updated and improved chart of accounts is being developed for implementation in 
2009. A road map for adoption of international public sector accounting standards has been 
approved to provide the basis for preparing the Government’s financial statements to be more in 
line with international practices. The Government is also laying the building blocks for improved 
governance and anticorruption measures. Since 2005, implementation of the State Audit Law 
and reporting of the summaries of annual audit reports by the State Audit of Vietnam have 
strengthened the process of external oversight. Under the World Bank’s PRSC series and 
ADB’s  SIPRP,  the  Government  is  working  on  improving  governance  in  recruitment  and 
promotion of civil servants, and development of an anticorruption strategy. The Government 
recognizes the need to measure progress and impacts of the PFM reforms and has indicated

33.  The objective of the CSF loan is to provide support for the Government’s countercyclical 
spending program for 2009 and, therefore, ensure predictability in its budget financing given the 
necessity for temporary fiscal expansion. This will allow the Government to support economic 
growth during a challenging period of weak global growth, protect its social spending and 
poverty alleviation programs and objectives, and continue with its longer term development 
objectives in 2009. 
34.  The Government has requested a loan of $500,000,000 under the CSF from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank-offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility  plus  200  basis  points;  a  5-year  term,

loan balance; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. The Government has provided 
ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility on

B.   Impact of the Government’s Countercyclical Public Spending Program   
 
3.  Economic  stimulus  effects. In times of a negative output gap, governments  may 
stimulate the economy through a combination of policy instruments such as (i) expansionary 
monetary policy, therefore lowering interest rates to stimulate investment and consumption; and 
(ii)  fiscal  expansion  through  tax  cuts  and  increasing  discretionary  public  spending.  An 
appropriate fiscal expansion will depend on its size relative to the output gap and the multiplier 
(or second-round) effects of the different components of the fiscal stimulus. Empirical evidence 
for  other  countries  indicates  that  infrastructure  spending  has  the  largest  multiplier  effects, 
followed by cash transfers to poor families; tax breaks have the lowest multiplier effects, as 
some proportion will be saved. 
 
4.  The Government is using both instruments to stimulate the economy. In aggregate, the 
national government budget deficit is projected at 10.3% of GDP or an expansion of 6.2% over 
2008 (budget deficit of 4.1% in 2008). Adjusting for budget revenue reductions in 2009 over 
2008 levels, the estimated fiscal stimulus is lower at 3.2%. This expansion is equivalent to about 
third-quarters of the negative output gap, indicating a sufficient expansion.  
 
5.  ADB staff estimates that without the fiscal stimulus, economic growth could bottom at 
about 2% in 2009 and recover to about 5.5% in 2010 in line with a modest global economic 
recovery. With the fiscal stimulus, economic growth is projected to pick up to 4.7% in 2009. The 
fiscal response is expected to carry over into early 2010 at a much smaller magnitude.  
 
6.  Poverty impacts. The economic slowdown of about 3%–4% of GDP in 2009 will reduce 
per capita income growth to 1.5%–3.5% in 2009. This could increase poverty in the short run 
through a weak labor market and reduced household earnings. Over the medium term, a slow 
economic recovery will create persistently high unemployment and suppressed earnings in the 
informal sector, as new labor market entrants outstrip new jobs created. This in turn will lead to 
persistently  higher  poverty.  The  Government’s  fiscal  stimulus  will  partially  offset  the 
unemployment and poverty impacts of the crisis, but an economic growth of about 6%–7% in

SUMMARY OF DEBT SUSTAINABILITY ASSESSMENT1 
 
1.  Background. Viet Nam’s debt position at the end of 2008 was estimated at 44.4% of 
gross domestic product (GDP), 56% of which (24.9% of GDP) is external debt. The Government 
has been prudent in external lending. Most of the country’s debt is at concessional, low interest 
rates with a well spread out maturity structure. With support from multilateral and bilateral 
development partners, the country’s debt is fairly diversified in terms of currency composition. 
Domestic public debt is also manageable. Its average implied interest rate at the end of 2008 
was about 6%. However, the bulk of amortization will fall due within 1–3 years. Viet Nam has 
strong access to significant non-debt-creating financing from strong private remittances and 
large foreign direct investment (FDI). 
 
2.  Main assumptions. The baseline scenario assumes the following:  
 
(i)  Real GDP growth will average 6.5% per year during 2009−2013 (below the last 
10-year  historical  average  of  7.2%)  and  will  decline  gradually  thereafter  as 
Viet Nam’s level of development begins to converge with its more advanced 
neighbors.  
(ii)  Inflation will decline from an average of 23% in 2008 to 6% in 2009 and will 
remain  at  that  level  through  2013.  Inflation  will  further  decline  thereafter, 
reflecting productivity gains. 
(iii)  The average interest rate of foreign borrowing will rise gradually from around 3% 
in 2008 to above 4% by 2028, reflecting a declining share of concessional loans. 
(iv)  The primary fiscal deficit (including off-budget expenditure and net lending) will 
rise to 6.5% in 2009 and gradually fall to 3% of GDP in 2013, and decline further 
to 2% on average during 2014–2028.  
(v)  Net capital inflows will fall from about 10% of GDP in 2008 to 8% in 2013 and 
stabilize thereafter. 
(vi)  Government financing from the fiscal stimulus and contingent liabilities are not 
included in the base line scenario. 
 
3.  External debt sustainability. Under the baseline scenario, the present value of external 
debt is projected to increase slightly in the short term, but will decline over the longer term. 
Reflecting a very open and dynamic characteristic of the economy, the present value of external 
debt as a share of exports is low and projected to decline from 27% in 2007 to 13.5% in 2028. In 
2008, the debt service ratios in relation to exports (3.4%) and to revenue (3.5%) were low. The 
two ratios are projected to decline after an initial increase. Stress tests indicate that external 
debt is most sensitive to exchange rate depreciation and a loss of access to non-debt-creating 
flows. A 30% one-time depreciation of the dong would increase the present value of external 
debt in relation to GDP by 8 percentage points relative to the baseline. A loss of access to non-
debt-creating flows will increase the present value of external debt by 3 percentage points by 
2013. A loss of access to concessional loans would have a similar negative effect but with a 
longer time horizon.

because of a significant deterioration in the overall fiscal balance. The present value of public

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues  
 
Viet Nam has been severely affected by the global economic downturn because of the country’s increasing dependence on 
foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows and exports to support its high economic growth rate since its successful accession to 
the World Trade Organization (WTO) in January 2007. FDI disbursement dropped by 18.4 and exports declined by about 
10.2% in the first half of 2009. Remittance inflows and tourist arrivals also dropped significantly. The global financial crisis also 
affected the Government’s market access for budget financing. As a result, the Government has not issued any bond 
domestically  since  early  2009  as  bond  yields  in  the  market  remain  significantly  higher  than  the  ceilings  set  by  the 
Government. The Government is concerned about the potential adverse poverty impacts of significantly slower economic 
growth. Because of the country’s young demographic profile, about 1.7 million young workers enter the labor force annually. 
During 2006–2007, with gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaging 7.6%, only about 800,000 jobs were created 
annually.  Since  growth  is  projected  to  decline  to  5%  or  less,  unemployment  and  underemployment  could  increase 
significantly. At the same time, the social security system is still in a very early stage of its development. The Government’s 
cash transfer program has limited coverage, and is fraught with implementation problems. Therefore, preventing a collapse of 
economic activities and sustaining employment are the most effective social security response.

The VIE-CS provides budget support for the Government’s countercyclical public spending program in infrastructure and the 
social sectors. It is aimed to ensure predictability in budget financing for 2009, as a larger national government budget deficit

support—through the Poverty Reduction Support Credits (PRSC) process—policy actions that 
are critical steps in carrying out the reforms and are important to ADB’s operations in Viet Nam.  
 
2.  The SIPRP V supports policy actions in the following four broad reform areas: 
 
(i)  Business  development.  Improving  the  financial  management  and  corporate 
governance  of  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs),  developing  the  financial  and 
private sectors, and improving the quality of infrastructure services. Key policy 
actions in this area include (a) strengthening the financial management of SOEs 
and their investments in other entities, and defining the level of such investments; 
(b)  developing  a  regulatory  framework  to  enhance  monetary  policy 
implementation and improve financial sector stability; (c) adopting a contingency 
plan to address potential adverse effects stemming from the global financial crisis 
on the banking sector; (d) promoting development of small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs) through revising regulations, formulating an action plan for 
supporting industries, and improving coordination among responsible ministries; 
(e) adopting a pricing system for electricity from renewable energy and providing 
incentives  for  government  procurement  of  energy-efficient  equipment;  and 
(f) revising the road law to improve traffic safety through measures including 
better standards and strengthened supervision of commercial vehicle operators, 
and setting up a monitoring and evaluation framework for the implementation of 
government policies post-World Trade Organization accession. 
 
(ii)  Social inclusion. Improving the quality of health care and education and access 
to these services by (a) formulating an education development strategy to 2020, 
(b) preparing a strategic plan to ensure prudential and effective investment of 
social  security  funds,  and  (c)  issuing  regulations  to  assign  institutional

setting  out  preventive,  demand-side,  and  sector-specific  solutions,  and 
monitoring mechanisms. 
 
3.  Key features of the SIPRP V include the following. First, it follows the program-based 
approach and is, in some respects, a continuation of SIPRPs I–IV. It provides parallel financing 
with the World Bank’s PRSCs within the framework of the PRSC process. Like the SIPRP IV, it 
is  intended  to  help  the  Government  carry  out  policy  reforms  needed  for  the  successful 
implementation  of  the  SEDP  2006–2010.  Second,  it  takes  the  program  cluster  approach 
consisting  of  three  chronologically  ordered  subprograms  with  a  well-defined,  medium-term 
framework  specified  at  the  outset  and  including  completed  high-impact  reforms  prior  to 
consideration  by  the  Board.  It  includes  triggers  for  subsequent  subprograms  to  ensure  a 
continuous dialogue between the Government, development partners, and stakeholders. Broad-
based,  well-targeted  policy  actions  designed  to  achieve  a  continued  reduction  in  poverty 
enhance Viet Nam’s economic competitiveness and strengthen the foundations for inclusive and 
sustainable growth and a continued reduction in poverty beyond 2010. In this way, the SIPRP V 
provides a coherent medium-term reform strategy with three discrete but linked subprograms

FISCAL STIMULUS PACKAGES: INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCE 
 
1.  This  appendix  summarizes  the  determinants  of  the  size  and  composition  of  fiscal 
stimulus packages and draws on the findings a number of recent International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) cross-country studies.1 Two sets of factors help explain the relative size of stimulus 
packages: (i) differences across countries in the need for stimulus, and (ii) differences in fiscal 
space. 
 
2.  Need  for  stimulus.  The  magnitude  of  the  overall  fiscal  expansion  (including  both 
discretionary and nondiscretionary components) should depend on the size of the output gap 
that each country faces in the absence of fiscal support. The fiscal expansion in a particular 
country should also be larger if multipliers are lower.   
 
3.  Composition of stimulus. Fiscal stimulus packages are typically comprised of (i) tax-
related measures, (ii) social sector spending, and (iii) infrastructure expenditures. However, the 
weight given to any one of these components depends on preexisting fiscal characteristics. 
Countries in which the automatic stabilizers are smaller (e.g., those that have less extensive 
social benefits programs) will require greater discretionary stimulus—this is true of most of the 
countries  in  Asia  in  relation  to  developed  economies.  Tax  stimulus  measures  can  be 
implemented relatively quickly and their impact is already being felt in the fiscal accounts. 
Expenditure measures, however, tend to proceed more slowly, reflecting normal budgetary 
controls and typical start-up delays in new programs. Multipliers, however, tend to be higher for 
expenditure-related  stimulus  measures  than  for  tax-related  ones.  Figure  A10  provides  a 
breakdown of the composition of stimulus packages in selected Southeast Asian countries. 
Finally,  coordination  of  stimulus  packages  across  countries  is  crucial  to  maximizing  their 
effectivity in the context of a global crisis. 
 
4.  Differences in fiscal space. Key factors that determine a country’s fiscal space to 
expand include levels of deficits, public debt, contingent liabilities, and interest rates.  Countries 
facing relatively higher real interest rates or elevated debt levels have less room to expand; 
competing crisis-related needs, such as for financial sector support (mainly in the United States 
and Europe), are also factors in determining available fiscal space. 
 
5.  Increasing  fiscal  space.  The  available  fiscal  space  can  be  increased  through 
appropriate policy design. Ideally, a larger fiscal expansion in times of economic crisis can be 
accommodated if policy design increases the likelihood of a fiscal tightening once conditions 
improve, to ensure long-term fiscal solvency. In this respect, the IMF has offered a number of 
recommendations: 
 
(i)  Stimulus packages should not have permanent effects on deficits. Table A10.1 
provides  a  cross-country  comparison  of  stimulus  packages  in  terms  of  the 
permanent or temporary nature of their fiscal impact. 
(ii)  Medium-term fiscal frameworks should clarify governments’ commitment to fiscal 
correction once economic conditions improve. 
(iii)  Structural reforms should be implemented to enhance growth, and thus medium-
term revenue prospects.
